newsitem.title: FRANCE: Luxembourg's Poos sees no threat to euro in France.
newsitem.headline: Luxembourg's Poos sees no threat to euro in France.

text.p: Luxembourg Foreign Minister Jacques Poos said on Friday he saw no threat to the single European currency nor to closer European integration whether the left or the right won France's parliamentary election.

In an article in the daily Le Monde, published two days before the first ballot, Poos effectively countered warnings from conservative French President Jacques Chirac and Prime Minister Alain Juppe that a left-wing victory could endanger European monetary union and weaken France's voice.

"An analysis of the election platforms of the two big political families shows that the European commitments and deadlines will be met. Neither the deepening of the European Union nor the euro will be called into question," he said.
Poos is the senior socialist in the Grand Duchy's broad coalition government led by Social Christian Prime Minister Jean-Claude Juncker.

The foreign minister said that whoever won the French poll, he hoped Paris would seek to boost the social dimension of the European Union, with the support of Luxembourg, which will hold the presidency of the EU in the second half of this year.
"The future French government could contribute to balancing out monetarist tendencies with an 'economic government' of the Union," Poos said.

"The future European central bank, while respecting the clauses of the treaty, cannot operate in isolation from political and social Europe: its currency, as its economy, must be at the service of human beings," he said.
